newsitem.title: USA: U.S. jobless claims rose in latest week.
newsitem.headline: U.S. jobless claims rose in latest week.

text.p: U.S. Labor Department report of initial state jobless benefit claims, seasonally adjusted.
Week Ended Initial Claims 4-Week Avg. Continued Claims
R-Revised, March 22 Initial Claims from 310,000, March 22 4-Week Average from 311,250, March 15 Continued Claims from 2,281,000, and March 8 from 2,310,000.
Wall Street economists had forecast initial jobless claims of 310,000 in the March 29 week.
Continued claims in the latest week were the lowest since the week ended Dec 23, 1989, when they were 2,291,000, the department said.
Labor said three states reported decreases in claims exceeding 1,000 on an unadjusted basis in the week ended March 22, the latest period for which data are available.
They were Tennessee, with 2,468 fewer filings; Oregon, with 1,596; and New York, with 1,220.
Tennessee reported fewer layoffs in the food, apparel, trade and service industries and in agriculture. Oregon and New York gave no reasons for the dropoff in filings in their states.
Three states reported increases in claims exceeding 1,000 in the March 22 week.
They were Maryland, with 2,608 additional filings; Louisiana, with 1,847; and Ohio, with 1,114.

Maryland said it had layoffs in the fabricated metals, transportation equipment, publishing, optical goods and service industries. Louisiana and Ohio both reported layoffs in the transportation equipment industry.
